why-currying-makes-our-code-better.text: Why Currying Makes our Code Better

mainly-some-functions-take-config-data-a.text: Mainly, some functions take ‚Äúconfig‚Äù data as input

when-do-we-apply-this-idea.text: When do we apply this idea

pageProps.body:
The Power of Currying

https://blog.bitsrc.io/functional-programming-part-3-the-powers-of-currying-213eb69b234b

What is Currying

A curried function is a function that keeps returning functions until all its params are fulfilled

How Currying Works

Why Currying

Currying will make our code:

  1. Cleaner
  2. Less repetitive params passing and less verbose code
  3. More composable
  4. More reusable

Why Currying Makes our Code Better

Mainly, some functions take ‚Äúconfig‚Äù data as input

If we have functions that take ‚Äúconfig‚Äù params, we better curry them because these ‚Äúconfigs‚Äù will probably be repeated over and over again.

If we have functions that take ‚Äúconfig‚Äù params, we better curry them because these ‚Äúconfigs‚Äù will probably be repeated over and over again. For example, let‚Äôs suppose we have a translator function, that takes a locale and a text to be translated:

const translator = (locale, text) => {
  /*translation*/
}

The usage would look like this:

translator("fr", "Hello")
translator("fr", "Goodbye")
translator("fr", "How are you?")

Every time we call translator we should provide locale and text. Which is redundant and dirty to provide the locale on every call. But instead, let‚Äôs curry translator like this:

const translator = curry((locale, text) => {
  /*translation*/
})
const inFrench = translator("fr")

Now inFrench has fr as locale provided to the curried translator function and waits for text to be provided. We can use it like this:

inFrench("Hello")
inFrench("Goodbye")
inFrench("How are you?")

Currying did us a great favour indeed, we don‚Äôt need to specify the locale each time, instead the curried inFrench has locale due to currying. After currying -in this specific example. Code is:

  1. Cleaner
  2. Less verbose and less redundant Because we separated ‚Äúconfig‚Äù from actual ‚Äúdata‚Äù. Which is quite handy in many areas and use cases.

Why separate ‚Äúconfig‚Äù from ‚Äúdata‚Äù params?

Many components and functions need the use of some functionalities (translate in our case) but shouldn‚Äôt or can‚Äôt know about the ‚Äúconfig‚Äù part (locale). Where these components or functions have the ‚Äúdata‚Äù only part (text). So these functions will be able to use that function without the need of knowing about the ‚Äúconfig‚Äù part.

Thus, that component or function will be less coupled with the system, which will make the components more composable and more maintainable.

When do we apply this idea

Closure and Currying Relationship

A Closure: is a function returned by a ‚Äúparent‚Äù function and has access to the parent function‚Äôs internal state. (described earlier here) Currying: will always result a closure. Because each function returned by a curried function will be provided with parents‚Äô internal state.

More Examples

  - boredom -> easy fun -> art -> profit?

> I've often described my motivation for building software to others using imagery: I like to go find a secluded beach, build a large, magnificent sand castle, and then walk away. Will anyone notice? Probably not. Will the waves eventually destroy it? Yep. Did I still get immense satisfaction? Absolutely. - [aliasxneo](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=41497113)

> We love to see the process, not just the result. The imperfections in your work can be beautiful if they show your struggle for perfection, not a lack of care. - [ralphammer](https://ralphammer.com/is-perfection-boring/)

> Simplicity, even if it sacrifices some ideal functionality has better survival characteristics than the-right-thing. - [The Rise of Worse is Better](https://www.dreamsongs.com/RiseOfWorseIsBetter.html)

> [Roberto Blake was talking about making 100 crappy videos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OnUBaQ1Sp_E) to get better over time. Putting in the reps and improving a little bit each time.
>
> Putting in the work without expecting any external reward at first (eg views, followers, likes, etc) will pay off in the long run. - [100 Scrappy Things](https://www.florin-pop.com/blog/100-scrappy-things/)

> Make the difficult habitual, the habitual easy, and the easy beautiful. - [Constantin S. Stanislavski](https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/7102271-make-the-difficult-habitual-the-habitual-easy-and-the-easy)

> A good match is a **structured** dance, where players aim to **score** while they are following well-defined **rules**. This **freedom within a structure** is what makes it fun. - [ralphammer](https://ralphammer.com/how-to-get-started/)

  - non-judgmental aspects of personality that can be strengths in some contexts and weaknesses in others
  - Pivot Points are fixed in the short term

- [Hedged Bets](https://longform.asmartbear.com/predict-the-future/#hedged-bets)
  - trading slightly less maximum upside for predictable, net-positive outcomes.
